2023 Narrative: Inception workshop on equitable access to water and sanitation30 October 2023TiranaThe UNECE-WHO/Europe Protocol on Water and Health encourages its Parties to ensure access to water and sanitation for everyone and places particular emphasis on providing equitable access to water and sanitation ‚Äúfor all members of the population, especially those who suffer a disadvantage or social exclusion‚Äù (article 5, l). In line with this, the Protocol provides a sound framework and effective tools for translating the human rights to water and sanitation into practice, achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and implementing the European Union Directives on water and sanitation.As a Party to the Protocol, Albania will conduct a self-assessment using the Equitable Access Score-card, an analytical tool designed for governments and other stakeholders to establish a baseline, track progress and prompt discussion on further action to ensure safe access to water and sanitation for all. The Water Resources Management Agency of Albania, in collaboration with the Ministry of Health and Social Care, will lead the process institutionally.Followed by Montenegro, Albania will be the second country to pilot the draft revised Score-card on a river basin scale. The revised Score-card aims to reflect the lessons learned in the ten-year application of the tool and the experiences gained from the COVID-19 pandemic in the safe provision of water and sanitation services. Consequently, the objective of the inception workshop is to officially launch the project in Albania and provide an opportunity for a broad range of stakeholders from government, water regulators and civil society to come together and contribute through their expertise in identifying challenges and priorities for action and to be continuously involved in the process.A findings workshop is foreseen in Q1 for 2024 in which the results of the data collection process will be presented to all stakeholders for discussion and finalisation of the country report. Description: Funded by IOM Sasakawa Endowment Fund. The Kahriz is a traditional decentralized water supply system in Azerbaijan, which is fed through subterranean water. It has played a vital role in accessing groundwater extraction since ancient times in the arid zones of Azerbaijan. It is estimated that at least 1,400 Kahrizes exist in 20 regions of Azerbaijan. There is a growing recognition of Kahrizes as a nature-based solution and of the importance of rehabilitating them as an eco-friendly method for water extraction, especially in the face of climate change and water scarcity. In light of the above, the objective of this project is to contribute to enhanced water-related adaptation in the context of long-term impacts of climate variability and change in the Republic of Azerbaijan. The project will support government entities and project stakeholders to promote Kahriz rehabilitation as a climate change adaptation measure (Outcome 1) by making available evidence-based data and analysis promoting the rehabilitation of Kahrizes (Output 1.1) and by increasing the awareness and understanding of national stakeholders on the benefits of the Kahriz as a climate change adaptation measure, and equipping them to mobilize private investment (Output 1.2).

Description:
The project "Enhancing Capacities for Climate-Resilient Water Management " aims to address these gaps by integrating the economic assessment of natural capital into climate-resilient water management practices. Building upon Nature-based Solutions (NbS) and Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) approaches, the project will enhance institutional capacity to develop net-zero pathways and long-term strategies in the agricultural sector, while strengthening the capacity of local government and farmers. By focusing on the value of natural capital, the project will emphasize the economic benefits of sustainable water management, thereby justifying incentives for behavioral change towards these practices.
Moreover, this project aims to improve the capacity of stakeholders to enhance carbon sinks in agricultural land and enhance carbon sequestration in communities through NbS at natural ecosystem levels. By developing a novel methodology for the economic assessment of natural capital and applying it in water management, the project will contribute to more resilient communities and ecosystems in Turkmenistan.

The project will achieve environmental benefits as increased climate change resilience, Land Degradation Neutrality (LDN), increased Soil Organic Carbon (SOC), decrease in Green House Gas (GHG) emissions by addressing both the drivers of land degradation and biodiversity loss, enhancing their synergies and reinforcing the links between CBD, UNFCCC and the UNCCD. The two key elements of the project are: (1) the soft component with a focus on the promotion of climate change adaptation at local level, as well as of the long-term strategies at the institutional level, and (2) the hard components, leveraging the NbS and IWRM under the strategies to enhance carbon sinks, conserve high-carbon ecosystems and decrease non-CO2 emissions, while simultaneously increasing farmer resilience.

2024 Narrative: The project provided reliable and sustainable water supply solutions for communities affected by the Kakhovka Dam breach in Ukraine, particularly in Pokrov town, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast. The breach had left the community without access to clean drinking water due to the malfunctioning of the emergency power station, disrupting water supply from the Kakhovka reservoir. As an interim measure, IOM supported local authorities by delivering drinking water via water trucking. However, a durable solution was implemented by diverting water from the Bazavluk River to the Pokrov water treatment plant.Key activities included constructing a water intake structure, installing a pumping station, building a 2,600-meter technical water pipeline, and rehabilitating water filtration units. The system was powered by alternative energy sources, reducing reliance on the damaged Kakhovka Dam infrastructure. IOM supported Vodokanal in procuring materials such as pipes, pumps, filters, and control systems, ensuring environmental sustainability and efficient water management practices.The project benefited approximately 51,600 people in Pokrov and surrounding settlements, providing a long-term solution to water shortages and significantly enhancing community resilience.

Considering the importance of clean water for populations in human settlements in conflict-affected areas, in humanitarian response and in the long-term perspective, UNESCO proposes the application of the UNESCO World Water Quality Portal for operational water quality monitoring in a Dnipro River Basin area via Earth observation satellites with the aim at helping Ukrainian people have insight into the quality of water of the Dnipro River and the reservoirs along the Dnipro River, which provide water supplies to major cities of Ukraine, including the capital city Kyiv. Hence, the project provides vital information on the quality and safety of the water for the local populations and internally displaced persons relying upon for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene during the conflict.
The operational application of the UNESCO World Water Quality Portal in Dnipro River in Ukraine will enable water quality monitoring via the use of Earth observation satellites and in-situ measurements and as a result will provide valuable data and information on water quality of the Dnipro River and the reservoirs along the river. Water quality data retrieved from Earth observation satellite images will be calibrated. The availability of (historic or new) in-situ water quality monitoring data in the project area is highly recommended to ensure the calibration and scientific validation of the algorithms and satellite-retrieved data.

Description:
Clean, safe water is essential for populations in conflict-affected areas and emergencies. In these areas, populations are exposed to higher risks of consumption of contaminated drinking water due to disruptions of water treatment and supply services, which may result in water-borne diseases. Consequently, access to safe drinking water is crucial for the survival of people living in conflict-affected areas, especially for children and women. It is vital for local populations to have the means to verify the quality and safety of the water they rely upon for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene when the access to water treatment and supply services is disrupted.
Consequently, UNESCO proposes the distribution of simple water quality testing kits and portable laboratory kits to schools and local communities in conflict-affected areas, as such kits provide vital information on the quality and safety of the water for the local populations and internally-displaced persons relying upon for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene during the conflict.
